title: 114_hr6345
content: The "TPS Reform Act of 2016" is the short title of this Act, which deals with Temporary Protected Status. The TPS Reform Act of 2016 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to designate a foreign state based on specific requirements related to armed conflict and personal safety threats for nationals. The TPS Reform Act of 2016 allows for the designation of a foreign state in cases of environmental disasters or inability to handle the return of nationals. The TPS Reform Act of 2016 allows for the designation of a foreign state based on extraordinary and temporary conditions preventing nationals from returning safely, with estimates of eligible individuals included in the Act. The TPS Reform Act of 2016 allows for the designation of a foreign state based on temporary conditions affecting nationals' immigration status in the United States, with a maximum effectiveness period of 18 months. Termination of the designation can occur if not extended or upon the enactment of an Act finding the foreign state no longer meets the criteria. The TPS Reform Act of 2016 allows for the designation of a foreign state based on temporary conditions affecting nationals' immigration status in the United States. The Act specifies that the designation can be extended for up to 12 months if the conditions for designation continue to be met. Additionally, amendments are made to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding aliens lacking lawful immigration status. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include that an alien lacking lawful immigration status can be designated under certain conditions. Conforming amendments are made to Section 244 of the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to designate aliens lacking lawful immigration status under certain conditions. Section 244 of the Act is further amended to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security."
